dek: How 390 high school dress codes are still sexualizing their students in 2019.
author: Amber Thomas
assistance: with data collection assistance from Kait Thomas and Anna Houston
preamble: If you aren't currently in high school, it's probably been a while since you've read a student handbook.  Over the past few months, my colleagues and I have pored over 420 of them from schools across the US.  We focused specifically on the dress code section — a set of policies hotly debated for being racist, sexist, and promoting sexualization.  This is a story of how we got here and what we found along the way.
introQuestion: In early 2017, writer Dana Schwartz posed a question to the Twitter-verse: "Ladies, when was the first time you were made to feel embarrassed and sexualized for what you wore?"

introMemory.value: I thought of my earliest memories of this type of behavior — the times when I wasn‚Äôt aiming to be ‚Äúsexy‚Äù, but was perceived that way anyway. I remembered the girls stopped outside of our middle school dance because their shoulders and underarms were bare. Holding my arms by my sides while an administrator checked the length of my shorts. Being handed a detention slip because a small sliver of the skin on my torso was exposed. Like Dana, each of my earliest memories of feeling sexualized came from adults that were trying to enforce my school‚Äôs dress code.
I like to imagine that this wasn‚Äôt done maliciously. I mean, it‚Äôs not like my school‚Äôs policy actually said anything like this:

convo1ReceivedText: Ladies, your bodies are too sexy and need to be covered up.

introMessage.value: But that doesn‚Äôt mean that I hadn‚Äôt still received that message. Like so much else in life, words can often hold hidden meanings or insinuations.
For instance, at their core, enforcing dress codes requires information about what a student wears to school. Imagine if that was presented like this:

introLede.value: The words themselves are harmless enough, but they are tinged with culture-specific meaning. In this case, they bring with them an inherent suggestion of sexuality.

Without a knowledge of cultural contexts, computers are often terrible at separating out explicitly written words from their underlying meaning. In text-only environments, humans are bad at this too. That‚Äôs why many online forums have started using the ‚Äú/s‚Äù notation to indicate sarcasm. All of this makes any quantification of words‚Äô implied meaning challenging. That is, adding data to this conversation is difficult.
This is a story about weaving the words written in more than 420 high school dress codes together with research and reports about the implied meanings of the things we find.

bodyIntro.value: According to the American Psychological Association (APA), one way to separate sexualization from healthy sexuality is based on whether or not the person is being objectified. In other words, if a person is being perceived as a sexual object which exists for the pleasure of others, instead of an independent person whom is capable of making their own judgments and decisions on what is right for them, they are being objectified and thus sexualized.

Many have argued that dress codes often meet this qualification. They suggest that at best, by prohibiting certain body parts from being visible, students receive the message that those body parts are important to others. At worst, some say that dress codes go so far as to turn whole people into a collection of inappropriate body parts to cover.
In our analysis, we found that around 80% of dress codes prohibited at least one body part from being visible. Those prohibitions often look something like this:

bodyExample: [Students may not wear] clothing that bares or exposes traditionally private parts of the body including, but not limited to, the stomach, buttocks, back and breasts.
bodyPostExample: Each of the figures below represents one school dress code. Any banned body parts have been removed from the figure. Hover or tap on any image to get a more zoomed in look.
bodyPartTitle: The Body Parts Prohibited in Each School
bodyPostMultiple: You may have begun to notice some trends amongst the dress code policies. These may become clearer if we aggregate the data from all 420 schools in our dataset.
bodyBarTitle: The Most Commonly Banned Visible Body Parts

bodyMid.value: But like the stories of dress code infractions that pop up across the country, we find more information about the trends in dress codes in the aggregate. Midriffs — the front part of your body between your chest and your waist — is the most banned body part by a long shot. Which raises the question: why?

In Western culture, the midriff, and navel in particular, has a long history of being seen as taboo or indecent. That is, the female midriff. In New York City, the female navel (i.e., belly button) was forbidden from being seen in public spaces until 1985. Arguments go on about whether baring the female midriff is fashionable, erotic, or attractive to those looking at her, but often don‚Äôt include the views of the people exposing their tummies.

bodyOutro.value: Midriffs — the front part of your body between your chest and your waist — is the most banned body part by a long shot. Which raises the question: why?

The stomach and belly button are not inherently sexual body parts. Though, in Western culture, the midriff, and navel in particular, has a long history of being seen as taboo or indecent. Specifically, the female midriff. Ladies couldn‚Äôt show their belly buttons in Hollywood until x and in New York City the female navel was forbidden from being seen in public spaces until 1985. These days, it‚Äôs more culturally acceptable in many spaces, though schools are clearly slow to come around to tummy-bearing attire. Arguments go on about whether baring the female midriff is fashionable, erotic, or attractive to those looking at her, but always seem to focus on the people that are observing someone else‚Äôs midriff, rather than the person bearing their own.

This practice of commenting on someone else‚Äôs body and imposing sexuality upon them (whether they intended to be ‚Äúsexy‚Äù or not) falls squarely into the APA‚Äôs definition of sexualization. Compounding the issue, some argue, is that by telling and showing students that these body parts are important to others, we are reinforcing the idea that those parts should be important to the student too. Unfortunately for students, studies have shown that when people of any age are consciously thinking about their appearance, they perform worse on various cognitive tasks like math tests and are more likely to experience eating disorders, low self-esteem, and depression.

clothesIntro.value: Of course, dress codes prohibit more than just specific body parts from being visible. As suggested by their name, they often list a number of items that students are not allowed to wear to school. While they can inclue all sorts of things from a requirement to wear shoes to leaving the spiked jewelry at home, let‚Äôs focus specifically on clothing items that are worn on your body.  This includes any form of shirt, pants, shorts, skirts, dresses, and undergarments.

Through our analysis, we found 48 items or styles that were banned for students at least 5% of the time. Although the rules are generally written to affect all students evenly, many of them affect some students more than others. For instance, although male students are also not allowed to wear halter tops, that fashion item is typically made and marketed to girls.
Let‚Äôs see which of the banned clothing items are specifically marketed to girls, boys, or students of any gender.

clothesGraphTitle: Percentage of High Schools Which Prohibit Clothing Items

clothingNotesText.value: * the definition of ‚Äúshort‚Äù varies from school to school. The most common lengths for shorts, skirts, and dresses were ‚Äúto the students fingertips‚Äù (46%), ‚Äúlonger than mid-thigh‚Äù (34%), and ‚Äúlonger than the knee‚Äù (8%). Another 34% didn‚Äôt specify a length, just prohibited ‚Äúshort‚Äù items of clothing. ‚ÄúShort‚Äù shirts refers typically to shirts that can‚Äôt be tucked in or touch the top of the pants.

clothesOutro.value: You may have noticed that almost all of these items are likely prohibited because they reveal parts of the body. In fact, there are only 3 (pajamas, gym shorts, unhemmed pants) that seem to be banned from schools for any reason beyond ‚Äúcovering the body‚Äù.

Of the remaining 40 items, x% are marketed to girls, y% to any gender, and only z% marketed to boys. Once again we see that the bodies and clothes that girls are wearing are more highly regulated than other students.

wordsTitle: The Words We Tell Our Students

wordsIntro.value: Even after dress codes ban body parts and clothes that expose the body, making it clear that some parts of you should be hidden, the words we use further reinforce this idea. Most dress codes begin with a few sentences informing the reader what a dress code is for and why it exists.  You‚Äôll often find phrases like the following:

word-examples.text: Bizarre, immodest or revealing clothing demeans the value of the wearer and disrupts the educational atmosphere. It will not be permitted.
The purpose of the Dress Code is to encourage students to focus on the learning process without the distractions of unsuitable dress and grooming.

Students are encouraged to ask themselves the following questions when choosing what to wear to school:
Does my outfit promote modesty and respectability?
Does my choice of clothing make those around me uncomfortable?
Does my clothing expose too much?
The district‚Äôs dress code is established to teach grooming and hygiene, prevent disruption, and minimize safety hazards.

wordsMid.value: Our words matter. Whether intentionally or not, these dress codes are telling students (sometimes literally) that their bodies and modes of dress are distractions or linked to their value or self worth. And as we‚Äôve already seen, it is largely the female students that are receiving these messages.
We extracted the most common words used to describe students, their bodies, or their mode of dress in the dress code. Explore some examples of the most common words and phrases below.

wordsGraphTitle: Most Common Words in the Rationale for Dress Codes

methods.value: All school handbooks were chosen for analysis opportunistically as follows: I found a list of thousands of potential public high schools using the National Center for Education Statistic‚Äôs (NCES) search function for public schools. I limited the resulting schools to just those that had a web address listed and then accessed the homepage web content from each site searching for words like ‚Äúhandbook‚Äù, ‚Äúdress code‚Äù, and ‚Äúcode of conduct‚Äù, filtering my list of schools to just those that contain one of the above phrases. Then, I manually visited the resulting (2000+) websites in an attempt to find the dress code. Dress codes were disqualified from analysis if they: had a uniform policy, were not from the 2018-2019 school year, or represented schools that ‚Äúmagnet‚Äù or ‚Äúboarding‚Äù schools (according to the NCES).

Once the list of dress codes was compiled, I and two data assistants (Kaitlyn Thomas and Anna Houston) manually recorded every rule listed in each dress code, the words used in the dress code‚Äôs rationale, as well as any listed sanctions for breaking the dress code.

more.value: In the larger conversation around school dress codes, the sexualization of students is simply one part. Luckily, some amazing work has been done focusing on this and other areas as well:

more-list.title: Dress Coded: Black girls, bodies, and bias in D.C. schools
more-list.author: National Women‚Äôs Law Center and DC Students
more-list.text: Combining data from all but 3 of Washington DC‚Äôs public high school‚Äôs written dress code policies alongside the lived experiences of 21 black girls that attend/have recently attended those schools,  this report explores the effect of dress code policies on black girls. The authors of this report also discuss the impact of uniform policies on families and suggestions for how educators and policymakers can improve dress codes.

more-list.title: How dress codes criminalize males and sexualize females of color
more-list.author: Alyssa Pavlakis and Rachel Roegman
more-list.text: Pavlakis and Roegman surveyed an entire school‚Äôs student population (with a total of 384 responses) and 13 teachers to learn about how often students followed the dress code, were disciplined for breaking the policies, and their feelings about the dress code overall. They explore gender, race, and the intersection of the two.

more-list.title: Undressing the Dress Codes: An analysis of gender in high school dress code policies
more-list.author: Jaymie Arns
more-list.text: Through their Master‚Äôs Thesis, Arns dissects the dress codes in 56 public high schools in California (2016-2017 School Year) and how students at the intersections of gender and race are disproportionately targeted.

more-list.title: ‚ÄúTuck in that Shirt!‚Äù Race, class, gender, and discipline in an urban school
more-list.author: Edward Morris
more-list.text: Over the course of 2 school years, Morris observed and recorded the race, class, and gender influence on school disciplining of students‚Äô bodies and dress in a Texas middle school.

more-list.title: Model Student Dress Code
more-list.author: Oregon NOW
more-list.text: The Oregon National Organization for Women (NOW) created a model student dress code ‚Äúintended to address recent and escalating controversy and conversation both in Oregon and across the nation about overreaching and detrimental dress codes for some K-12 school students.

other.value: The words themselves are harmless enough, but they are tinged with culture-specific meaning, in this case they sexually suggestive.

The thing is, dress codes are tricky. These rules were written, seemingly, in an attempt to cover up our bodies and prevent them from being sexualized. But their enforcement does just the opposite, turning people into a collection of inappropriate body parts to be covered. These types of policies are in the news constantly as students push back against the antiquated rules. But even with a never-ending list of examples, and research conducted on public schools in California and Washington DC, these issues are still often presented to the public as a series of isolated incidents. I wanted to better understand just how pervasive the sexualization of students is in dress codes, so we analyzed 390 public high school dress codes across the US for the 2018-2019 school year.

explicit-1: In case you haven‚Äôt read one in a while, high school dress codes are typically written as a list of items that students are prohibited from wearing.
explicit-2: When these policies are called ‚Äúsexist‚Äù you may imagine that these policies are explicitly gendered. That is, that the policy is written to only affect one group of students. Here‚Äôs an example:
explicit-3: In this case, male students are being singled out and explicitly prohibited from wearing earrings, a fashion item that female students are still allowed to wear. We found gendered prohibitions like this in 28% of schools. Here are the most common items allowed for some students and prohibited for others.

explicit-4.value: While technically legal, policies like these promote gender stereotypes and can be especially damaging to LGBTQ and non-cisgender students.
But this isn‚Äôt the only way that dress codes target certain types of students.

createIntro1: It may seem like the easiest way to eliminate sexism (and racism) in dress codes is to leave out any explicit prohibitions for certain groups of students. That is, frame all prohibitions like this:
createExample: Male students may not wear earrings
createIntro2: Let‚Äôs put that theory to the test. Below, you‚Äôll find the 24 most commonly prohibited items in high schools across the US. Use them to create your own dress code. We aren‚Äôt allowing you to ban items for one type of student or another, so any items that you ban will be banned for all students.
createInstructions: Tap the items below that you would NOT ALLOW in your dress code.
postCreate: Alright, let‚Äôs take a look at the items you‚Äôve prohibited.
genHisTitle: Percentage of Prohibited Items Primarily Worn by Groups of Students
genHisSubTitle: Per High School, Compared to All Prohibited Items
raceHisTitle: Percentage of Prohibited Items Primarily Worn by Students of Color
preRace: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Vestibulum scelerisque, nisl in finibus placerat, diam ipsum pharetra neque, ac rhoncus magna ante sit amet turpis. Vivamus sed arcu scelerisque, sollicitudin mi eget, sodales magna.

resultProseGen.value: Although you were not allowed to explicitly ban clothing items for a single group of students in this exercise, we did allow you to prohibit clothing items that are primarily worn by specific groups of students. That is, typically, we would expect strapless tops to be worn more often by students that wear feminine clothing than masculine ones whereas students that wear masculine clothing are more likely to wear hats to school.

It looks like x of your prohibited items are primarily worn by feminine students, x by masculine students, and x of your items were gender neutral. As you can see, this is an easy trap to fall into, and many schools policies end up banning large percentages of clothing items that are not explicitly prohibited for one group of students, still really target one group of students implicitly.

resultProse: Of the clothes that you prohibited:
resultRaceProse: are worn primarily by students of color
